questions.question: Evaluate the definite integral \(\int_1^2 x^2\sqrt{x^3+1}\,dx\).
Evaluate \(\int_0^{\pi/6}\cos^2 x\sin x\,dx\).
questions.explanation: Let \(u=\cos x\), \(du=-\sin x\,dx\). When \(x=0\), \(u=1\); when \(x=\pi/6\), \(u=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\). Integral \(=-\int_1^{\sqrt{3}/2}u^2\,du=\int_{\sqrt{3}/2}^1 u^2\,du=\frac{u^3}{3}\big|_{\sqrt{3}/2}^1=\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{3}\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^3=\frac{1}{3}-\frac{3\sqrt{3}}{24}=\frac{1}{3}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{8}\).

questions.question: Evaluate \(\int_e^{e^3}\frac{2}{x}\,dx\).
A particle moves along the x‑axis with velocity \(v(t)=2t^2-10t+8\) ft/s. On the interval \([0,6]\), how many times does the particle change direction?
questions.explanation: Set \(v(t)=0\): \(2(t-1)(t-4)=0\) ⇒ \(t=1\) and \(t=4\). Check signs: \(v(0)=8>0\), \(v(2)=8-20+8=-4<0\), \(v(5)=50-50+8=8>0\). The velocity changes sign at both \(t=1\) and \(t=4\), so the particle changes direction 2 times.

questions.question: Find the average value of \(f(x)=3x^2+2\) on the interval \([1,4]\).
Let \(f(x)=x^4-5x+1\). Which of the following correctly applies the Intermediate Value Theorem to guarantee a zero on the given interval?
questions.explanation: IVT requires a sign change. \(f(1)=1-5+1=-3<0\) and \(f(2)=16-10+1=7>0\). Since \(f\) is continuous and changes sign on \([1,2]\), there must be a zero in that interval. The other options have no sign change.

questions.question: Find the general solution to the differential equation \(\dfrac{dy}{dx}=y^2\sin x\).
questions.explanation: Separate variables: \(\frac{dy}{y^2}=\sin x\,dx\). Integrate: \(-\frac{1}{y}=-\cos x+C_1\). Solve: \(\frac{1}{y}=\cos x-C_1\), so \(y=\frac{1}{\cos x+C}\) where \(C=-C_1\).

questions.question: Let \(F(x)=\int_0^{\sin x}\sqrt{1+t^2}\,dt\). Find \(F'(x)\).
questions.explanation: By FTC Part 1 and the chain rule: \(F'(x)=\sqrt{1+(\sin x)^2}\cdot\frac{d}{dx}(\sin x)=\cos x\sqrt{1+\sin^2 x}\).

questions.question: Differentiate \(f(x)=e^{3x^2}\).
Find \(f'(x)\) if \(f(x)=\csc(4x)\).
questions.explanation: Using the chain rule: \(\frac{d}{du}\csc u=-\csc u\cot u\). With \(u=4x\): \(f'(x)=-\csc(4x)\cot(4x)\cdot 4=-4\csc(4x)\cot(4x)\).

questions.question: Let \(f(x)=\begin{cases}x^2+x & x<2\\k & x=2\\3x & x>2\end{cases}\). Is \(f\) continuous at \(x=2\)? If so, what is \(k\)?
options: No; the left and right limits differ
questions.explanation: Left limit: \(2^2+2=6\). Right limit: \(3(2)=6\). Both equal 6, so the two-sided limit is 6. For continuity, \(k=f(2)=6\).

questions.question: Find all x‑values where \(f(x)=3x^5-5x^3\) has a point of inflection.
questions.explanation: \(f'(x)=15x^4-15x^2\), \(f''(x)=60x^3-30x=30x(2x^2-1)\). Set \(f''(x)=0\): \(x=0\) or \(x=\pm\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=\pm\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\). Verify sign changes at all three: \(f''\) changes sign at each, confirming all three are inflection points.

questions.question: Use implicit differentiation to find \(\dfrac{dy}{dx}\) for \(\sin(xy)=x\).
questions.explanation: Differentiate both sides: \(\cos(xy)\cdot(y+xy')=1\). Expand: \(y\cos(xy)+x\cos(xy)\cdot y'=1\). Isolate \(y'\): \(x\cos(xy)\cdot y'=1-y\cos(xy)\), so \(y'=\frac{1-y\cos(xy)}{x\cos(xy)}\).

questions.question: Find the equation of the normal line to \(y=e^x\) at the point \((0,1)\).
questions.explanation: \(y'=e^x\). At \(x=0\): tangent slope \(=e^0=1\). Normal slope \(=-1\). Equation: \(y-1=-1(x-0)\), so \(y=-x+1\).

questions.question: Let \(f(x)=\dfrac{x^2-1}{x^2+1}\). Find the instantaneous rate of change of \(f\) at \(x=2\).
If \(f(1)=3\) and \(f(5)=15\), find \(\int_1^5 f'(x)\,dx\).
questions.explanation: By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus: \(\int_1^5 f'(x)\,dx=f(5)-f(1)=15-3=12\).

questions.question: For \(f(x)=x^3\) on \([0,3]\), find the value(s) of \(c\) in \((0,3)\) guaranteed by the Mean Value Theorem.
Differentiate \(f(x)=\dfrac{\sin x}{x^2}\).
questions.explanation: Quotient rule: \(f'(x)=\frac{x^2\cos x-\sin x\cdot 2x}{x^4}=\frac{x\cos x-2\sin x}{x^3}\).

questions.question: A particle has velocity \(v(t)=t^3-6t^2+9t\) ft/s on \([0,5]\). Find the minimum value of the velocity on this interval.
Determine the intervals on which \(f(x)=x^4-4x^3\) is decreasing.
questions.explanation: \(f'(x)=4x^3-12x^2=4x^2(x-3)\). Since \(4x^2\geq0\) for all \(x\), the sign of \(f'\) is determined by \((x-3)\): \(f'(x)<0\) when \(x<3\) (and \(x\neq0\)). So \(f\) is decreasing on \((-\infty,3)\).

questions.question: Which of the following functions is NOT differentiable at \(x=4\)?
questions.explanation: \(f(x)=\sqrt{|x-4|}=|x-4|^{1/2}\) has a cusp at \(x=4\). Its derivative \(f'(x)=\frac{1}{2}|x-4|^{-1/2}\to\infty\) as \(x\to4\), so \(f\) is not differentiable there. The other three functions are smooth at \(x=4\).

questions.question: Water flows into a tank at a rate of \(r(t)=5t^2+3\) liters per minute. How many liters accumulate from \(t=0\) to \(t=4\) minutes?

The derivative \(f'(x)\) changes from negative to positive at \(x=-5\), from positive to negative at \(x=0\), and equals zero at \(x=4\) with \(f'\) negative on both sides. Classify each critical point.
options: Min at \(-5\), max at \(0\), neither at \(4\)
Max at \(-5\), min at \(0\), neither at \(4\)
Min at \(-5\), max at \(0\), min at \(4\)
Max at \(-5\), min at \(0\), max at \(4\)
questions.explanation: First Derivative Test: − to + ⇒ relative minimum at \(x=-5\); + to − ⇒ relative maximum at \(x=0\); no sign change (negative on both sides) ⇒ neither at \(x=4\).

questions.question: Find the area under the curve \(y=4-x^2\) above the x‑axis from \(x=0\) to \(x=2\).
At \(x=a\), a function satisfies \(f(a)<0\), \(f'(a)<0\), and \(f''(a)>0\). Which description best matches the behavior near \(x=a\)?
questions.explanation: \(f(a)<0\) means below the x‑axis; \(f'(a)<0\) means decreasing; \(f''(a)>0\) means concave up.

questions.question: Evaluate \(\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}(3\sin x+5)\,dx\).
questions.explanation: The function \(3\sin x\) is odd, so \(\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}3\sin x\,dx=0\). The constant term gives \(\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}5\,dx=5(2\pi)=10\pi\). Total \(=10\pi\).

questions.question: Find the area of the region enclosed by \(y=4-x^2\) and \(y=x+2\).
For \(f(x)=x^4-12x^2\), determine the interval(s) on which \(f\) is concave down.
Find the equation of the tangent line to \(f(x)=\ln(5x-4)\) at \(x=1\).
The side length of an equilateral triangle is increasing at 2 cm/s. At what rate is the area increasing when the side length is 8 cm?
questions.explanation: For an equilateral triangle: \(A=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}s^2\), so \(\frac{dA}{dt}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}s\frac{ds}{dt}\). With \(s=8\) and \(\frac{ds}{dt}=2\): \(\frac{dA}{dt}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}(8)(2)=8\sqrt{3}\) cm²/s.

questions.question: A population grows according to \(P(t)=300e^{0.06t}\). What is the population after 10 years? Express exactly.
Find all relative extrema of \(f(x)=x^3+3x^2-45x+7\) using the First Derivative Test.
options: Relative maximum at \(x=-5\); relative minimum at \(x=3\)
Relative minimum at \(x=-5\); relative maximum at \(x=3\)
questions.explanation: \(f'(x)=3x^2+6x-45=3(x+5)(x-3)\). Critical: \(x=-5,3\). Sign of \(f'\): positive for \(x<-5\), negative for \(-5<x<3\), positive for \(x>3\). First Derivative Test: + to − ⇒ relative max at \(x=-5\); − to + ⇒ relative min at \(x=3\).

questions.question: Find the value of \(k\) that makes \(f(x)=\begin{cases}5x-1 & x\le3\\x^2+k & x>3\end{cases}\) continuous at \(x=3\).
questions.explanation: Left limit (and value): \(5(3)-1=14\). Right limit: \(3^2+k=9+k\). Set equal: \(9+k=14\) ⇒ \(k=5\). Verify: \(9+5=14\) ✓

questions.question: Use the Trapezoidal Rule with \(n=4\) equal subintervals to approximate \(\int_0^4\sqrt{x}\,dx\).
Find the critical points of \(f(x)=\sin x+\cos x\) on \([0,2\pi]\).
The base of a solid is the region bounded by \(y=4-x\) and \(y=0\) from \(x=0\) to \(x=4\). Cross sections perpendicular to the x‑axis are squares. Find the volume.
questions.explanation: Side of each square = \(4-x\). Cross-sectional area = \((4-x)^2\). Volume \(=\int_0^4(4-x)^2\,dx=\left[-\frac{(4-x)^3}{3}\right]_0^4=0-\left(-\frac{64}{3}\right)=\frac{64}{3}\).

questions.question: At what x‑value on \(y=\sqrt{x}\) is the tangent line parallel to \(y=\dfrac{1}{4}x+2\)?
Is \(f(x)=|x^2-9|\) differentiable at \(x=3\)? Justify.
options: No, because the left and right derivatives at \(x=3\) are \(-6\) and \(6\) respectively, which are not equal
Yes, because the function is continuous at \(x=3\)
No, because the function is not continuous at \(x=3\)
questions.explanation: For \(x<3\): \(f(x)=9-x^2\), so the left derivative at \(x=3\) is \(-2(3)=-6\). For \(x>3\): \(f(x)=x^2-9\), so the right derivative is \(2(3)=6\). Since \(-6\ne6\), \(f\) is not differentiable at \(x=3\).

questions.question: Let \(H(x)=\int_1^{x^2}\tan(t)\,dt\). Find \(H'(x)\).
questions.explanation: By FTC Part 1 and the chain rule: \(H'(x)=\tan(x^2)\cdot\frac{d}{dx}(x^2)=2x\tan(x^2)\).

questions.question: Evaluate \(\displaystyle\lim_{x\to0}\frac{1-\cos(3x)}{x^2}\).
questions.explanation: This is a \(\frac{0}{0}\) form. Apply L'Hôpital's Rule: \(\lim\frac{3\sin(3x)}{2x}\). Still \(\frac{0}{0}\). Apply again: \(\lim\frac{9\cos(3x)}{2}=\frac{9}{2}\) as \(x\to0\).

questions.question: A square piece of cardboard of side 12 in. has equal squares of side \(x\) cut from each corner and the sides folded up to form an open box. Find the value of \(x\) that maximizes the volume, and state that maximum volume.
Use the Second Derivative Test to classify the critical points of \(f(x)=x^4-8x^2+6\).
options: Relative maximum at \(x=0\); relative minima at \(x=\pm2\)
Relative minimum at \(x=0\); relative maxima at \(x=\pm2\)

questions.question: Use a right Riemann sum with \(n=3\) equal subintervals to approximate \(\int_0^3(x^2+2)\,dx\).
Find \(\dfrac{d}{dx}\left[\arctan\!\left(\dfrac{x}{3}\right)\right]\).
A particle has position \(s(t)=t^4-8t^2\). Find the acceleration at each moment when the velocity is zero.
Find the absolute maximum and minimum values of \(f(x)=x^3-3x+1\) on \([-2,3]\).
options: Absolute max \(19\) at \(x=3\); absolute min \(-1\) at \(x=-2\) and \(x=1\)
Absolute max \(3\) at \(x=-1\); absolute min \(-1\) at \(x=1\)
Absolute max \(19\) at \(x=3\); absolute min \(-3\) at \(x=0\)
Absolute max \(3\) at \(x=-1\); absolute min \(-1\) at \(x=-2\)

questions.question: Solve the initial value problem \(\dfrac{dy}{dx}=\dfrac{3x^2}{y}\), \(y(0)=4\).
A particle moves with velocity \(v(t)=\sin(2t)\) ft/s on \([0,\pi]\). Find the total distance traveled.
Differentiate \(f(x)=(4x^2-3x+1)^7\).
Use linear approximation at \(x=2\) to estimate \(f(2.01)\) where \(f(x)=x^4\).
